eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object. This action must be called after the object has moved for the frame.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCameraCloser

events.comment: The camera following is called with an action, the call from doStepPreEvents must be disabled to avoid to do it twice.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object.
eventsFunctions.name: DoMoveCameraCloser

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX))
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY))
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SpriteMultitouchJoystick
description: Multitouch joysticks are objects showing a joystick on the screen, useful for mobile. They work like a physical gamepad:
- 4 or 8 directions
- Analogus pads
- Player selection

- Automatic "mapper" behaviors for 2D and 3D movement behaviors (platformer characters, top-down movement, 3D character etc...). Add one of these to the object with the movement behavior (i.e: the player most of the time) and the behavior will then be controlled automatically by the virtual joystick (it works by reading the multitouch joystick state and simulating controls). No need for additional events to make it work once the behaviors are set up.
There are ready-to-use joysticks in the asset-store [multitouch joysticks pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=multitouch-joysticks-multitouch-joysticks).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Ahnaf30e
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FPS
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Calculate and display the frames per second (FPS) of the game.
description: Provides an expression to get the current FPS and a text object behavior to display the current FPS.
Frames Per Second (FPS) describes how many times in the last second your game logic was executed.
This includes running behaviors and events, and then rendering the new game state into the game window. The higher the FPS, the more fluid and performant your game looks.
Note: Use the Performance Profiler (inside in the Debugger) for detailed performance information about your game.

events.name: Keep timestamps for every frame inside the lookback period

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RenderToSprite
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Renders an object, layer, scene or an area of a scene and puts the resulting image into a sprite.
description: Allows rendering (creating an image) of objects, layers and the scene to display in a sprite.
This allows to make optimizations by transforming the resulting image of a shape painter into a faster sprite, or to make viewports/cameras.

eventsFunctions.description: Renders an object and puts the rendered image into a sprite object.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Render an object into a sprite
eventsFunctions.name: RenderObject

inlineCode: // Reset position so that it is not offscreen while rendering
const { x: originalX, y: originalY } = source.position;
const { width, height, x, y } = source.getLocalBounds();
// Ensure the target is a RenderTexture of the correct size

eventsFunctions.fullName: Render a layer into a sprite

eventsFunctions.name: RenderSceneArea
eventsFunctions.sentence: Render the area of a current scene into Sprite: _PARAM1_, from OriginX: _PARAM2_, OriginY: _PARAM3_, with Width: _PARAM4_, Height: _PARAM5_

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Silver-Streak, @Bouh, Tristan Rhodes
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: IsOnScreen
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This adds a condition to detect if an object is on screen based off its current layer.
description: This extension adds conditions to check if an object is located within the visible portion of its layer's camera. The condition also allows for specifying padding to the virtual screen border.
Note that this does not take into account any object visibility, such as being hidden or 0 opacity, but can be combined with those existing conditions.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
This behavior provides a condition to check if the object is located within the visible portion of its layer's camera. The condition also allows for specifying padding to the virtual screen border.
Note that object visibility, such as being hidden or 0 opacity, is not considered (but you can use those existing conditions in addition to this behavior).
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: InOnScreen

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if an object position is within the viewport of its layer.
eventsFunctions.name: IsOnScreen

inlineCode: Get the object layer, convert the position from this layer to the screen coordinates.
Get the point on each side on the object on screen, and compare with the screen area.
This way even if the camera has a rotation or custom scale the object is always compared to the screen area.
// Get the layer of the object.
// Get the aabb of the object on his layer.
// Get the layer to convert the coordinates of the AABB to the screen coordinates
// Get the points on each side of the object on screen.
const posLeftObjectOnScreen = Math.min(topLeft[0], topRight[0], bottomLeft[0], bottomRight[0]);
const posRightObjectOnScreen = Math.max(topLeft[0], topRight[0], bottomLeft[0], bottomRight[0]);
const posUpObjectOnScreen = Math.min(topLeft[1], topRight[1], bottomLeft[1], bottomRight[1]);
const posDownObjectOnScreen = Math.max(topLeft[1], topRight[1], bottomLeft[1], bottomRight[1]);

parameters.longDescription: Number of pixels to pad the screen border. Zero by default. A negative value goes inside the screen, a positive value go outside.
parameters.name: Padding

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: StayOnScreen
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move the object to keep it visible on the screen.
description: Force the object to stay visible on the screen by setting back its 2D position (X and Y coordinates) inside the viewport of the camera.
The shoot'em up example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://space-shooter)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Force the object to stay visible on the screen by setting back its 2D position inside the viewport of the camera.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: StayOnScreen

eventsFunctions.description: the top margin (in pixels) to leave between the object and the screen border.
eventsFunctions.name: MarginTop

eventsFunctions.description: the bottom margin (in pixels) to leave between the object and the screen border.
eventsFunctions.name: MarginBottom

eventsFunctions.description: the left margin (in pixels) to leave between the object and the screen border.
eventsFunctions.name: MarginLeft

eventsFunctions.description: the right margin (in pixels) to leave between the object and the screen border.
eventsFunctions.name: MarginRight

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ButtonStates
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Use any object as a button and change appearance according to user interactions.
description: Use the "Button states" behavior to track user interactions with an object, including:
- Hovered
- Pressed
- Clicked
- Idle
Add additional behaviors to make juicy buttons with animated responses to user input:
- Size
- Color
- Animation
- Object effects

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.
